Hi Stephen,

Well, as you say, this is a subjective area, but I'll list som=
e of the
reasons why I think the first example is convoluted:

   - It's us=
ing a reverse logic:  enter catch -> good, proceed as usual
   -> bad.  Thi=
s is highly counter-intuitive.
   - It has an empty catch statement (always=
 a code smell in my book),
   hence the necessity to add a no-op call or a =
comment to say "it's okay, I
   know what I'm doing".
   - It doesn't expre=
ss its intent clearly (if I show you three tests
   with try/catch, you won=
't be able to tell right away which ones test for
   exceptions and which o=
nes don't).

On the other hand, the annotated code expresses its intent cle=
arly (it
almost reads as plain English), doesn't drown the signal in noise =
and is
much shorter.

It's actually a perfect example where annotations are=
 clearly an improvement
over the "old way", in my opinion...
